indicators.justification:
Canada tracks and reports on greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions (1), including emissions from land use activities (2) and from large facilities (3). Every year, Canada prepares and submits a national greenhouse gas (GHG) inventory to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) (4)(5).

(1) Greenhouse gas emissions, Environment and natural resources Canada. https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/environmental-indicators/greenhouse-gas-emissions.html

(2) Land-based greenhouse gas emissions and removals, Environment and natural resources Canada.  https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/environmental-indicators/land-based-greenhouse-gas-emissions-removals.html

(3) Greenhouse gas emissions from large facilities, Environment and natural resources Canada.  https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/environmental-indicators/greenhouse-gas-emissions/large-facilities.html

(4) Greenhouse gas emissions: inventories and reporting, Environment and natural resources Canada.  https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/climate-change/greenhouse-gas-emissions.html

(5) Greenhouse gas emissions: inventories and reporting, Government of Canada. https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/779c7bcf-4982-47eb-af1b-a33618a05e5b

evidence.title: Greenhouse gas emissions: inventories and reporting

indicators.justification:
The Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada (COSEWIC) is an independent advisory panel to the Minister of Environment and Climate Change Canada that assesses the status of wildlife species at risk of extinction and submits an annual report (1).
Results are maintained in a public registry (2).

(1) Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada. https://www.cosewic.ca/index.php/en-ca/

(2) Species at risk public registry, Environment and natural resources Canada. https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/species-risk-public-registry.html

evidence.title: Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada
Public registry of species at risk

indicators.justification:
There are disparate datasets about climate vulnerability addressing the two approaches: the risks and hazards approach, which focuses on responding to natural hazards (1), extreme weather events (2), air and water quality (3) and the entitlements and livelihoods approach, that analyse data on gender diversity and inclusion (4) and aboriginal people (5).

(1) Natural Hazards of Canada, Public Safety Canada. https://www.publicsafety.gc.ca/cnt/mrgnc-mngmnt/ntrl-hzrds/index-en.aspx
(2) Drought Watch and agroclimate, Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada. https://agriculture.canada.ca/en/agriculture-and-environment/drought-watch-and-agroclimate
(3) Households and the Environment Survey, Statistics Canada. https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/en/surveys/3881
(4) Gender, diversity and inclusion statistics, Statistics Canada. https://www.statcan.gc.ca/eng/topics-start/gender_diversity_and_inclusion
(5) Aboriginal Peoples Survey, Statistics Canada. https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/en/surveys/3250

indicators.justification:
Canada does not have an online or offline registry of beneficial owners. In the 2018-2020 National Action Plan on Open Government, they commited to increasing corporate transparency (1). In 2020, the government launched a consultation about establishing a public registry to combat money laundering, terrorist financing and tax evasion, while balancing privacy concerns (2). Since March 2021, they released a new guidance document to all reporting entities that details when and how to collect and verify beneficial ownership information (3, 4). More recently, in the Annual Budget released on April 19th, the Government of Canada announced the plan to implement a publicly accessible beneficial ownership registry for corporations in Canada by 2025 (5).

Sources:
(1) Canada's 2018-2020 National Action Plan on Open Government, 2018. https://open.canada.ca/en/content/canadas-2018-2020-national-action-plan-open-government

(2) Public consultations on strengthening corporate beneficial ownership transparency in Canada, 2020. https://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/142.nsf/eng/00001.html

(3) Public consultations on strengthening corporate beneficial ownership transparency in Canada: What we heard, 2021. https://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/142.nsf/eng/00002.html

(4) Beneficial ownership requirements, 2021.
https://www.fintrac-canafe.gc.ca/guidance-directives/client-clientele/bor-eng

(5) Lawrence E. Ritchie, Elizabeth Sale, Malcolm Aboud, Haley Adams and Chelsea Rubin, 2021. Canada's budget introduces long-awaited beneficial ownership registry to combat money laundering https://www.osler.com/en/blogs/risk/april-2021/canada-s-budget-introduces-long-awaited-beneficial-ownership-registry-to-combat-money-laundering

evidence.title: Canada’s 2018-2020 National Action Plan on Open Government - Section 3
Canada’s budget introduces beneficial ownership registry

indicators.justification:
Civil registration of births, marriages and deaths are managed at a provincial and territorial level, while national statistics are the responsibility of the federal agency - Statistics Canada.

To access records, one should consult the respective local website or office (1). Statistics Canada maintains non-public databases for birth (2), stillbirth (3) and death (4), subject to confidentiality restrictions, with data collected from provincial and territorial partners, and conducts studies and statistics that can be available online (5).

(1) Vital Statistics Council for Canada, Statistics Canada. https://www.statcan.gc.ca/eng/about/relevant/vscc/organisations 
(2) Vital Statistics - Birth database, Statistics Canada. https://www23.statcan.gc.ca/imdb/p2SV.pl?Function=getSurvey&Id=1287741 
(3) Vital Statistics - Stillbirth Database, Statistics Canada. https://www23.statcan.gc.ca/imdb/p2SV.pl?Function=getSurvey&Id=1295387 
(4) Vital Statistics - Death database, Statistics Canada. https://www23.statcan.gc.ca/imdb/p2SV.pl?Function=getSurvey&Id=1313663 
(5) Data, Statistics Canada. https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/en/type/data

evidence.title: Provincial and territorial offices and websites
Select "Vital Statistics - Birth" (or stillbirth or death) under "Survey or statistical program"

indicators.justification:
There is no real-time data about the capacity of the healthcare system. However, there is a PPE supply and demand marketplace that keeps track of the number of critical products like face shields, respirators, and testing kits available to buy (1). There is also a platform with supply and demand visibility for free exchange of PPEs (2). Another page keeps track of drug shortages in Canada (3). CritiCall Ontario help hospital-based physicians in Ontario who are lacking the needed resources to call an agent who can locate a hospital or physician to care for their urgent patient by consulting a database (4). Public Services and Procurement Canada posted a call for suppliers on its portal in March 2020 to secure the equipment and supplies needed to fight Covid-19 and received more than 26,000 unique submissions (5). 

(1) Canadian PPE Supply Marketplace, RRP. https://www.rrpcanada.org/#/ 
(2) Covid PPE Help. https://covidppehelp.ca/ 
(3) Drug Shortages Canada. https://www.drugshortagescanada.ca/ 
(4) CritiCall Ontario. https://www.criticall.org/Article/Urgent-and-Emergent-Support
(5) Public Services and Procurement Canada. https://buyandsell.gc.ca/supplying-goods-and-services-in-support-of-canada-s-response-to-covid-19

indicators.justification:
The Public Health Agency of Canada maintains vaccination data web resources compiled from multiple sources such as provincial and territorial websites and partners. This covers supply and distribution data updated every Tuesday and Thursday (1), vaccine administration data across provinces updated every day (2), demographic coverage updated every Friday (3), indigenous people (4) and inmates vaccination (5).


(1) Vaccines for COVID-19: Canada's vaccine supply, Government of Canada. https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/covid-19-vaccine-treatment/vaccine-rollout.html 
(2) COVID-19 Vaccination in Canada: Vaccines Administered, Government of Canada. https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/vaccine-administration/ (3) COVID-19 Vaccination in Canada: Vaccines Coverage, Government of Canada.  https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/vaccination-coverage/ 
(4) COVID-19 vaccines and Indigenous peoples, Indigenous Services Canada. https://www.sac-isc.gc.ca/eng/1606941379837/1606941507767 
(5) Vaccines administered to inmates in the federal correctional system, Government of Canada. https://www.canada.ca/en/correctional-service/campaigns/covid-19/vaccine-csc/vaccine-table.html

The data includes information about the geographic distribution of vaccinations.
The data includes information about the age of the people who have been vaccinated.
The data includes information about the sex and/or gender of the people who have been vaccinated.

The data includes information about membership in a marginalized population among the people who have been vaccinated.
The data includes information about vaccination for residents of long-term care facilities.
The data includes information about vaccination for residents of prisons and jails.

indicators.justification:
There is a dataset that covers aggregate statistics on land use accross Canada (1). More granular land use data can be found on the Open Government Portal (2), local governments' websites and Natural Resources Canada maps data. In particular, forests data (3)(4) and protected areas data (5) have their own databases.

Sources:
(1) Land Use Survey, Statistics Canada. https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/fa8e76e5-9cad-4262-bbf0-a2a038666ce2
(2) Land Use, Open Government Portal. https://search.open.canada.ca/en/od/?sort=score%20desc&page=2&search_text=land%20use%20
(3) Forests Maps, Natural Resources Canada. https://www.nrcan.gc.ca/maps-tools-publications/tools/geodetic-reference-systems/forest-maps/16874
(4) National Forestry Database. http://nfdp.ccfm.org/en/index.php
(5) Canadian Protected and Conserved Areas Database, Environment and natural resources. https://www.canada.ca/en/environment-climate-change/services/national-wildlife-areas/protected-conserved-areas-database.html

indicators.justification:
There is a dataset that covers aggregate statistics (size and number of farms reporting) about land owned, rented, leased from governments, crop-shared, used through other arrangements or used by others, at the level of subregions of provinces (1). Data about individual parcels of lands are handled by provincial governments: some provinces have online registries with specific access restrictions and search criteria, others requires contacting a registry office (2). A residential property database, initialized in 2017, continues to be expanded and is expected to contain information for all properties in Canada by December 2022 (3). Indigenous people have three land registries (4). More datasets on land tenure can be found on Open Data Canada portal (5).

Sources:
(1) Land Tenure, Statistics Canada.  https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/b9c8bd17-f2be-43db-b6d6-e1ff63fcc1ed

(2) Land Registry Offices in Canada, Title Searchers. https://www.titlesearchers.ca/registries/

(3) Canadian Housing Statistics Program, Statistics Canada. https://www23.statcan.gc.ca/imdb/p2SV.pl?Function=getSurvey&SDDS=5257

(4) Land Registration, Indigenous Services Canada. https://isc.gc.ca/eng/1100100034803/1611929056890

(5) Land Tenure, Open Government Portal. https://search.open.canada.ca/en/od/?sort=score%20desc&page=1&search_text=land%20tenure

evidence.title: Tenure of land owned, leased, rented, crop-shared, used through other arrangements or used by others
Provincial land tenure registries and offices

indicators.justification:
Government of Canada InfoBase is the authoritative source of Government planned and actual budgetary expenditures expenditure information (1). The related datasets can be found on the Open Data portal (2).
 
(1) Infobase, Government of Canada. https://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/ems-sgd/edb-bdd/index-eng.html#orgs/gov/gov/infograph/financial
(2) InfoBase Open Datasets, Government of Canada. https://open.canada.ca/data/en/dataset/a35cf382-690c-4221-a971-cf0fd189a46f

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

(2) Open Data, Office of the Commissioner of Lobbying of Canada. https://lobbycanada.gc.ca/en/open-data/

indicators.justification:
Canada does not have a comprehensive national framework for data reuse (1). It does however encourage good data practices to increase data reuse (2)(3). The Tri-Agency Statement of Principles on Digital Data Management by The Canadian Institutes of Health Research, the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada, and the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada is a good example (4). Furthermore, the Shared Services Canada (SSC) department published a data strategy that aims to harmonize and consolidate authoritative source systems, deriving maximum value out of the data in their repositories (5).

Sources:
(1) A Canadian Framework
for Data Reuse, Michel Girard, Center for International Governance Innovation, 2018. https://www.cigionline.org/static/documents/documents/no.251.pdf

(2) Statistics Canada Data Strategy, 2019. https://www.statcan.gc.ca/eng/about/datastrategy

(3) Report to the Clerk of the Privy Council: A Data Strategy Roadmap for the Federal Public Service, 2018. https://www.canada.ca/en/privy-council/corporate/clerk/publications/data-strategy.html#toc0

(4) Tri-Agency Statement of Principles on Digital Data Management. https://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/063.nsf/eng/h_83F7624E.html

(5) Shared Services Canada Data Strategy, 2019. https://opencanada.blob.core.windows.net/opengovprod/resources/7f39eb21-3740-4aed-869f-dbcf67d0e22e/shared-services-canada-data-strategy-2019-2021.pdf?sr=b&sp=r&sig=UHMqOckty5DmcPLhwMbclj5IVXHLBD6aXlK1AvtMkp0%3D&sv=2015-07-08&se=2022-01-15T18%3A03%3A36Z

evidence.title: A Canadian Framework for Data Reuse
Report to the Clerk of the Privy Council: A Data Strategy Roadmap for the Federal Public Service
Tri-Agency Statement of Principles on Digital Data Management.

indicators.justification:
Given Canada's federal structure, regional and local open data initiatives are led by the corresponding subnational governments. All 10 provincial governments  and 2 of the 3 territorial governments have open data initiatives. Additionally, approximately 100 Canadian cities have open data initiatives, including the national capital (Ottawa), 11 of the 13 provincial/territorial capitals, and several large cities (e.g., Montréal, Calgary, Vancouver). Links to many of these open data portals and policies can be found at Open Government Across Canada (1).
Many subnational governments also have open data initiatives and policies.

Source:
(1) Open Government Across Canada. https://open.canada.ca/en/maps/open-data-canada

The Canada School of Public Service established the CSPS Digital Academy to help in developing digital knowledge and skills of public servants (1). Very few specialized courses for data centred roles exist.

indicators.justification:
The Government of Canada supports data interoperability with a standardized federal metadata schema and common vocabulary as required under the Standard on Metadata for all departments and agencies (1). Until recently, all departments were responsible for publishing proactive disclosure information on their own websites. As per the proactive publication process, the central publishing platform for open data and proactive disclosure reporting on open.canada.ca supports high quality open data and enables interoperability through standardized data templates and rich metadata standards (2)(3). Interdepartmental working groups are collaborating on the development of federal reference data standards to enable data interoperability and develop a federal data quality framework across the federal government (4). This work supports the Policy and Directive on Service and Digital and aligns with the priorities identified in the Digital Operations Strategic Plan (5).

Sources:
(1) Standard on Metadata, 2010. https://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/pol/doc-eng.aspx?id=18909
(2) Open Government Guidebook, 2018. https://open.canada.ca/ckan/en/dataset/9eaa6d0e-4b8c-5241-acf7-c6885294b8c1
(3): Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat, Proactive Publication Process. https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/services/access-information-privacy/reviewing-access-information/proactive-publication-process-map.html
(4) Report to the Clerk of the Privy Council: A Data Strategy Roadmap for the Federal Public Service, 2018. https://www.canada.ca/en/privy-council/corporate/clerk/publications/data-strategy.html
(5) Digital Operations Strategic Plan, 2018. https://www.canada.ca/en/government/system/digital-government/government-canada-digital-operations-strategic-plans.html

evidence.title: Report to the Clerk of the Privy Council: A Data Strategy Roadmap for the Federal Public Service

indicators.justification:
There is a guide for preparing government-to-government or inter-departmental Information Sharing Agreements involving personal information (1). It applies to public institutions that are subject to the Privacy Act.
 
To reduce the number of surveys to be completed by Canadians, Statistics Canada enters into data-sharing agreements with provincial and territorial statistical agencies and other government organizations -as specified respectively in section 11 and 12 of the Statistics Act (2)- who are required to use data only for statistical purposes and to comply with specific terms and conditions, with regard to the access, confidentiality and security of the information they received (3).

Sources:
(1) Guidance on Preparing Information Sharing Agreements Involving Personal Information, 2010. https://www.canada.ca/en/treasury-board-secretariat/services/access-information-privacy/privacy/guidance-preparing-information-sharing-agreements-involving-personal-information.html#Toc267044410

(2) Statistics Act, 1985. https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/S-19/FullText.html

indicators.justification:
The Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada is responsible for protecting personal information, through enforcing two federal laws: the Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA) for the private sector (1), and the Privacy Act for the public sector (2). In 2020, they launched a consultation on regulating artificial intelligence as it relates specifically to PIPEDA (3). A new bill (C-11) was introduced with the Consumer Privacy Protection Act at its core and, once enacted, it is set to replace parts of the PIPEDA, modernizing and extending rules governing the collection, use, and disclosure of personal information for commercial activity in Canada (4).

Sources:
(1) The Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA), 2000. https://www.priv.gc.ca/en/privacy-topics/privacy-laws-in-canada/the-personal-information-protection-and-electronic-documents-act-pipeda/
(2) The Privacy Act, 1985. https://www.priv.gc.ca/en/privacy-topics/privacy-laws-in-canada/the-privacy-act/
(3) Consultation on Artificial Intelligence by the Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada, 2020. https://www.priv.gc.ca/en/about-the-opc/what-we-do/consultations/completed-consultations/consultation-ai/
(4) Bill C-11, 2020. https://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/csj-sjc/pl/charter-charte/c11.html

evidence.title: The Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act (PIPEDA)

indicators.justification:
The Open Government Division within the Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat (TBS) is in charge of Canada's open government and open data initiatives. The Directive on Open Government, Canada's "open by default" policy in place since 2014, states clear and mandatory requirements to departments to release government data of business value to support transparency, accountability, citizen engagement, and socio-economic benefits (1). The Access to information act provides requirements for proactive disclosure of some government data (such as contracting, grants, and travel expenses) and for the right to request information in records under the control of a government institution.

Canada launched their 4th National Action Plan on Open Government (2018-2020) with 10 new commitments promoting openness, transparency, and accountability, to be completed in June 2021 (2). They recently conducted consultations for their 5th National Action Plan which is expected to be published in Fall 2021 (3). 
After leading the Open Government Partnership for a year as a co-chair, the Government of Canada hosted the 6th Open Government Partnership Global Summit in May 2019. 
They have a multi-stakeholder forum that supports dialogue with civil society and provides continuous input on their initiatives. The official open government Canada website (open.canada.ca) compiles resources such as a searchable open data portal (that includes datasets, maps, apps, APIs, etc.) and the open government license (4).

Sources:
(1) Directive on Open Government, 2014. https://www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/pol/doc-eng.aspx?id=28108

(2) Canada's 2018-2020 National Action Plan on Open Government, 2018. https://open.canada.ca/en/content/canadas-2018-2020-national-action-plan-open-government

(3) Consultation for Canada's 5th National Action Plan on Open Government, 2020. https://letstalkopengov.ca/

(4) Open Government Website. https://open.canada.ca/en

(5) Open Data Across Canada. https://open.canada.ca/en/maps/open-data-canada

evidence.title: Canada’s 2018-2020 National Action Plan on Open Government

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework establishes a common definition of open data.
The framework promotes open licensing without any restrictions beyond attribution and share-alike.
The framework requires to publish data in machine readable formats.
The rules/guidance requires the use of specific data standards.
The framework promotes training and capacity building among government officials.

responses.response_text: The relevant laws, policies and guidance assessed cover the majority of localities and government agencies.
responses.subquestion_text: How widely do these laws, regulations, policies or guidance apply?

evidence.title: Canada’s 2018-2020 National Action Plan on Open Government, 2018.

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
Summary reports must be provided as structured data.
Expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification must be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require executive budget proposal information to be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require the approved or enacted budget to be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require in-year reports as structured data.
The rules/guidance require year-end reports as structured data.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: The laws, regulations, policies or guidance assessed, or equivalent rules/guidance, apply across the whole public sector including national, sub-national, and local government.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive is the coverage of laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The Conflict of Interest Act (1) and the Code (2) govern the disclosure of assets, liabilities and gifts for public office holders and members of the House of Commons respectively, administered by the Conflict of Interest and Ethics Commissioner​.

(1) Conflict of Interest Act, 2006. https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/c-36.65/
(2) Political Financing Handbook, 2021. https://www.ourcommons.ca/About/StandingOrders/appa1-e.htm

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires collecting specific information on assets and liabilities.
The framework requires collecting specific information on in-kind and non-financial support.
The framework requires collecting information on significant changes in assets and liabilities.
The framework requires disclosure of income and assets held by a public official's spouse, family members, or other intimates.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The framework requires the publication of income and asset declarations.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The Lobbying Act (1) requires the collection and publication in a public registry of the identities of consultant or in-house lobbyists, lobbyists' clients or employers, and public officials who engage with lobbyists, as well as the goal and timimg of lobbying engagements; and sets out restrictions on lobbying activities. It empowers the Commissioner of Lobbying to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data and to conduct an investigation if he or she deems it necessary. The Lobbyists' Code of Conduct sets out the principles and rules of ethical behaviour expected from lobbyists focusing on transparency, proper use of information and avoiding conflict of interest (2).

(1) Lobbying Act, 1985. https://laws.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/L-12.4/

(2) The Lobbyists' Code of Conduct, 1997. https://lobbycanada.gc.ca/en/rules/the-lobbyists-code-of-conduct/lobbyists-code-of-conduct

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of lobbyists, lobbying clients, lobbying activities, and public officials.
The framework requires the collection and publication of the identities of lobbyists, lobbyist clients, and public officials who engage with lobbyists.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on lobbyists' goals for lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on timing of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on topics of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on how much money is spent on lobbying activities.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: The framework assessed covers the national government, but may have some exceptions or may not apply to other levels of government.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the lobbying framework assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
Canada Elections Act governs reporting requirements and publication of campaign and party finance data (1). The Political Financing Handbook provides guidance to registered parties with clear reporting schedules, in conjunction with the Act (2). The Chief Electoral Officer is responsible for enforcing the Act.

(1) Canada Elections Act, 2000. https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/E-2.01/index.html
(2) Political Financing Handbook, 2021. https://www.elections.ca/pol/pol/man/ec20231/2021-02_e.pdf

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of campaigning activities of parties, candidates, and third parties.

responses.response_text: The framework requires the public disclosure of the identity of any donor who contributes above a defined threshold.
responses.subquestion_text: The framework requires donors' identities be made public.
The framework requires collecting specific information on financial contributions.
The framework requires collecting specific information on assets and liabilities.
The framework requires collecting specific information on income and spending.
The framework requires collecting specific information on in-kind and non-financial support.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The framework requires regular updates, including updates in conjunction with campaigns and defined campaign schedules.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The Policy Statement and Guidelines for Public Participation is a resource for all Department of Justice managers and officials to help them organize public participation activities (1). It calls for providing background information materials for participants, giving participant sufficient time to respond, ​reporting to citizens on results and informing them how their input was used in devising the policy. It does not require collecting and publishing structured data.

(1) Policy Statement and Guidelines for Public Participation - Department of Justice, Government of Canada. https://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/cons/pol.html

evidence.title: Policy Statement and Guidelines for Public Participation - Department of Justice

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.

The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.

indicators.justification:
The Access to Information Act (1) requires collecting annual statistics assessing the compliance of government institutions with the Act and publishing a report containing a summary of those statistics, without specifying the exact metrics to be tracked.

(1) Access to Information Act, 1985. https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/a-1/

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in binding policy, regulations, or law.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results.
The framework requires that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification:
Due Diligence Canada provides comprehensive background research services across Canada, on a national, provincial and municipal level, using a variety of databases including open and subscription-based databases.

Source:
(1) Due Diligence Canada http://duediligencecanada.com/due-diligence/

responses.response_text: One or more products/services exist making use of open government datasets, and there is evidence of their widespread use.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used in products/services?
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, civil society
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.
There is evidence that at least one of the examples cited is making use of beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.

indicators.justification:
The Government of Canada maintains a page where they share impactful open data stories (1). One story is about Canada Energy Regulator (2) that uses land open data - including that of Indigenous lands - to better inform Canadians on pipeline locations and pipeline-related incidents to easily identify safety and environmental risks for pipeline and powerline projects, and help predict impacts of forest fire movements and flooding on pipelines and related facilities. Another is about Townfolio, a data as a service platform that collects city data from multiple sources and makes it more accessible (3). This includes Statistics Canada household data collected as part of their Census Program every five years, covering geographical information, such as population, education and household income. 

(1) Open Data User Stories, Government of Canada. https://open.canada.ca/en/stories

(2) Interactive Pipeline Map – A Visual Tool for Open Data. https://open.canada.ca/en/story/interactive-pipeline-map-visual-tool-open-data

(3) Townfolio – City Data as a Service. https://open.canada.ca/en/story/townfolio-city-data-service

evidence.title: Interactive Pipeline Map – A Visual Tool for Open Data
Townfolio – City Data as a Service
